Description: Large black-top red pottery bowl of Nile silt with many mending holes. The exterior is diagonally rippled, coated with red slip and broadly burnished in a perpendicular direction to the rippling. The interior is black, broadly and loosely burnished on the walls, with more pointed burnishing on the interior floor. Mending holes were drilled around most of the top, and part of the mid body, to repair breakage and cracks in antiquity.
Curator's comments: Brunton’s (1937) Black-topped Red BR24C. Pottery repaired by drilling and lashing is frequent in the Badarian period, suggesting that these fine ware vessels were not easily replaced.
Bibliographic references: Brunton 1937 / Mostagedda and the Tasian Culture (pl.16,24c.)
